round_1: ^My name is Cesar. It is nice to meet you.
^Sorry for my bad English. I used to live in Cyprus.

g-0: ^I like to be friendly, but trust is difficult. How do you make trust easy?

c-1: ^Oh, that's a tough one. At the very least, it certainly takes time!
^But how to reduce time? That we do not know.
c-2: ^I find both dogs and humans enjoy a good play together!
^This makes sense to me. Maybe we try one day? :)
c-3: ^Owner knows best, in my opinion. Strict rules and tough love means less disobedience!
^I can tell you, this does not work with me.

round_2: ^I have been playing with other dogs since our last talk. Much fun!

c-0: ^You look like you're enjoying yourself! You've come out of your shell quite a lot!
g-0: ^I do not know what this means.

c-1: ^It's an idiom! "A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words."
c-2: ^Don't worry. What matters is you're enjoying yourself!
^This is true! Unlike having a shell. As I say, I do not have one.
c-3: ^It's something English-speaking people say that means you're more social, or less shy!
^Aha! Like a snail! I understand now!

round_3: ^My English is getting better every day.
^I'm even using contractions! You see there?

c-0: ^I'm so happy for you! English isn't an easy language to learn, particularly for a dog!
g-0: ^Now that it has improved, I wish to explore all of England, and learn even more!
^Do you know of any routes to take?
^I am a living library of walks

c-1: ^I know so many walks, if you're up for them!
^Yes! It would bring me great joy!
c-2: ^Maybe we should start off with small walks around here first?
^Were we not given legs to explore, and mouths to communicate? Let us not waste these!
c-3: ^I've got a few up my sleeve.
^Another of your sayings! I understand these now!
